awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Small: Collaborative: Detecting and Characterizing Internet Traffic Interception Based on BGP Hijacking
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent reports have highlighted incidents of massive Internet traffic interception executed by re-routing Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) paths across the globe (affecting banks, governments, entire network service providers, etc.). The potential impact of these attacks can range from massive eavesdropping to identity-spoofing or selective content modification. In addition, executing such attacks does not require access or proximity to the affected links and networks, posing increasing risks to national security. Worse yet, the impact of traffic interception on the Internet is practically unknown, with even large-scale and long-lasting events apparently going unnoticed by the victims.

Because of the complex dynamics and number of different actors involved on a global scale, devising effective methodologies for the detection and characterization of traffic interception events requires empirical and timely data (e.g., acquired while the event is still ongoing).  Such data must be a combination of passive BGP measurements and active measurements (such as Traceroute), since the mechanism triggering the attack operates on the inter-domain routing control plane, but the actual impact is only verifiable in the data plane.

By leveraging our measurement and data processing infrastructure, this project aims to: (i) investigate, develop, and experimentally evaluate novel methodologies to automatically detect traffic interception events and to characterize their extent, frequency, and impact; (ii) extend the research team's measurement infrastructure to detect in near-real-time and report episodes of traffic interception based on BGP hijacking; and (iii) document such events, providing datasets to researchers and summary statistics and reports to operators, emergency response teams, law enforcement agencies, and policy makers.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet is vulnerable to a class of large-scale attacks---known as BGP route hijacking---with tremendous potential impact, threatening the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of network communications.  While the origin of these vulnerabilities lies in the design of the Internet global routing protocol (BGP), due to a mix of operational, regulatory, and economical issues, proactive solutions that address the problem at the root are struggling to take off. The vast majority of the defensive approaches adopted by network operators nowadays are therefore reactive, i.e., based on detecting and mitigating these attacks as they happen.  This project addressed the lack of comprehensive, efficient, and effective methods and tools for BGP hijacking detection.

Specifically, in this project, we developed scientific methods that can detect and characterize the impact of BGP route hijacking attacks.  We approached this problem from two distinct perspectives: (i) the point of view of an Internet operator (e.g., a service provider) wanting to detect attacks directed at its networks; (ii) a global monitoring standpoint trying to detect any BGP hijacking attack happening on the Internet. While the first point of view aims at immediately enabling operators to secure their networks, a global monitoring system can provide situational awareness, inform policy and regulators, and contribute to a better understanding of these phenomena and their impact.

We successfully introduced a comprehensive set of methods immediately adoptable by operators to detect attacks to their infrastructure, which we called ARTEMIS (Automatic and Real-Time dEtection and MItigation System). The ARTEMIS approach is attractive to operators because of its comprehensiveness (i.e., the ability to detect even sophisticated attacks), accuracy, speed, privacy and flexibility.  While we presented our approach to the most popular venues of Internet operators and technical experts, we also published it in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, where, based on extensive experimental work, we proved its effectiveness: for example, by performing experiments on the real Internet we showed how ARTEMIS was able to detect and mitigate BGP hijacking attacks within few seconds.  We then developed (with additional funding support and feedback from major network operators) an open source tool that implements the ARTEMIS methodology and we released ARTEMIS v1 to the public. Today ARTEMIS is already in use or under testing in several networks worldwide.

While ARTEMIS can leverage the knowledge of the configuration of the network it is protecting, its methods cannot be applied "as is" to the second scenario we targeted, that is, global Internet monitoring.  We therefore developed a set of new methods to detect suspicious BGP events on the Internet and to perform additional measurements while these potential attacks are happening in order to gather empirical data for their study and characterization. We published a peer-reviewed scientific paper presenting novel approaches to detect and classify various types of BGP hijacking events, including those performed through path manipulation or caused by accidental router misconfiguration. We implemented these methods in an experimental BGP hijacking observatory, running 24/7 at University of California San Diego.

While performing our research, in the first year of our project, we identified a technological and operational gap in the state of the art in terms of tools to efficiently process and analyze in real-time global Internet routing (i.e., BGP) data. To enable our research, we filled this gap by developing an open-source software framework called BGPStream.  BGPStream enables both simple and extremely complex BGP monitoring and analysis tasks and is today widely used by students and researchers from academia as well as practitioners and operators.  In addition, BGPStream is leveraged by the ARTEMIS tool to perform BGP monitoring and by our experimental BGP hijacking observatory.  We published a paper presenting BGPStream at the annual ACM Internet Measurement Conference, and received for this paper the prestigious Applied Networking Research Prize by the Internet Research Task Force.  

We broadly disseminated our results both to the scientific and operational community and engaged in collaboration with the industry, which benefited tech transfer and the professional development of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. Our goal in this project was to advance Internet infrastructure security by creating novel methodologies and instrumentation, as well as improving our understanding of phenomena such as BGP route hijacking.  The results of this project provide methods and tools for immediate application as well as a foundation for further development of reaction and mitigation strategies, and enabling more rigorous pursuit of cybersecurity research.
